title: Before 1 May 2020, will the Chicago Board Options Exchange's CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) close below 15.00?
preds:
As on 30 Apr, it is 31. From 01 Apr, from a high of 51, the chart is gradually climbing down to its normal level of 15-20. Surely, it will reach its pre - pandemic level, however, it will take time of gradual correction. Generally, the stock market has withstood the pressures of previous outbreaks and emerged stronger in  a 6-month to 1 year period.  
This pandemic is significantly different from the previous outbreaks causing huge economic negative impact by halting production and consumption of services and goods. Hence, the return to normalcy is expected to take a long time of more than a year.
The VIX has dropped about 13 point in 5 days. There is some small risk of it dropping from 33 to 15 in the next three days.
Extremely unlikely, but chance is not 0.  VIX has routinely fallen by 40%+ in very short periods of time.
Nothing in the trend line or on the news would suggest a steep enough decrease to warrant a sub 15 close in the coming days.
15% is too little even in good times. I would give it 0% even if the question was for the whole year.
unless there is a cure or treament or vaccine in the next two weeks that is not going to happen
VIX to come down only slowly
To much uncertainty for the index to drop that low.
I'm looking at its history after the beginning of the 2008, and it definitely took more than a couple of months to go back to the previous values. The current crowd forecast of 2% sounds about right.
still going to be in the air.

VIX,at 15 is roughly a normal level in a normal economy. Given that the current distancing measures have been extended until 4/30, and the fact that Trump today painted a pessimistic picture of the infection/death rates in the next two weeks, I don’t expect markets to reach a normal level for quite some time, at least in terms of investor anxiety and implied volatility.
It hasn't been that low since Feb

In addition to gpaumier's forecast, I checked the historical data from the last time the VIX was this high in 2008-09. It spiked in October 2008 did not drop below 20 until December 2019, over a year later. So I believe the chance that the current high volatility disappears by May is extremely low.
Gpaumier makes a lot of sense. Lowering it even more.

The VIX has been decreasing in the past couple days because traders think they now have enough information to properly gauge the impact of the pandemic on the market. My understanding is that very few people have an accurate view of how the crisis is going to affect the US in the next few months, particularly those whose livelihood relies on a stable and prosperous market. The exponential nature of the contagion, as well as the delays in the system, mean that this is only the beginning of the crisis. By May 1st, the reality and gravity of the situation will have become more apparent, in the form of more (and stricter) lockdowns, and number of reported casualties. This will fuel erratic markets, maintaining a high VIX. (There is a possibility that the gravity of the situation, and its economic consequences, could completely paralyze the markets and reduce the VIX. There is also a possibility that trading might be suspended, which would also reduce the VIX. I believe those possiblities are unlikely to happen, based on the widespread belief in the power of "The Market.")
Too soon for the Coronavirus to dissipate and the Markets to recover to that degree

The number of cases in the US is still exponentially increasing. Travel lockdowns is almost becoming global. Not sure how the market is going to become "peaceful" before Q2 PMI numbers are released. Unless between now and 1 May we have a confirmed vaccine that can be viably manufactured, I don't see how the VIX can go back to 15.

I'm a very high probability here. And my explanation "Sure, why not?" Oh, you say because "Look at it now!" "The world is falling apart!" I have traded VIX futures and I can tell you your perspective is narrow here. Either the VIX has a single day in the next month and a half that it closes below 15, or the high volatility causes escalating financial crises that seize the economy and make dealing with Corona look like sitting on a beach having a Corona. In other words, stabilizing the markets will become more of a priority than stabilizing a virus that kills only those who are already close-ish to death (not too much lost economic value, huh). And the powers that be will realize that they need to deescalate the COVID-19 situation for the economy.
The govenrment will not allow it.
Its a 66 now (March 3, 2020) and its low for the last 6 months is about 12.
Vol will remain high off back of protracted economic fears
After VIX spikes above 40 it usually takes longer than 6 weeks to return to levels below 15.
Historically always a long tail; reasoning from 2008
Volatility likely to stay high as cases spike in US and HC system supply chain threatens to break.  None of the CBOE futures suggest the hypo.

The last time the CBOE VIX closed below 15.00 was on 19 Feb 2020 [1]. Before the market opened on 20 Feb, news about the spread/lethality COVID-19 around the world began to create warning alarms in the news [2]. Today, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that the US government would re-assess the impact of the fiscal stimulus in the next 10-12 weeks [3], which means that the government is planning to issue a second stimulus due to the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Additionally, the market is pricing the VIX between 55.00 and 65.00 based on option chain analysis [4]. Additionally, many analysts are anticipating skyrocketing unemployment throughout the 2nd quarter with a possible spike up to 2 million claims across the country. During the last economic crisis, the CBOE VIX did not drop below 15.00 for the entirety of 2008 [1] and some economic leaders believe the economic impacts of COVID-19 could be worse/more volatile than the impacts of the 2008 economic crisis [6].  Thus, I assess a 2% chance that the CBOE VIX will fall below 15.00 before 1 May 2020. [1] http://www.cboe.com/vix
[2] https://www.cnn.com/asia/live-news/coronavirus-outbreak-02-19-20-intl-hnk/index.html
[3] https://www.forbes.com/sites/sarahhansen/2020/03/22/mnuchin-coronavirus-stimulus-deal-will-be-finalized-today-fed-will-lend-4-trillion-to-prop-up-economy/#5088451332e2
[4]http://www.cboe.com/delayedquote/quote-table?ticker=VIX
[5] https://techcrunch.com/2020/03/20/goldman-sachs-predicts-brutal-second-quarter-as-unemployment-spikes-above-2-million/
[6] https://www.newsweek.com/andrew-yang-warns-coronavirus-fallout-could-worse-2008-financial-crisis-support-grows-1492408
I see crowd is lower. I have a history of easing into things and then changing to a more radical number. Will bow to what I have read and the crowd and lower.

VIX has been going up not down. 11 to 85 in last 52 weeks. https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/VIX:IND
Checked futures and no one has them going that low at this point.
not a chance below but i predict not far off

Volatility will remain high until at least the summer, probably longer. Even if virus is contained by then, of which I am doubtful. The economy will be extremely unsettled, and with that, so will markets.

chances are low but the market has already been pricing in large bouts of volatility these past few months and it definitely will become worse before it gets better. Unemployment will absolutely follow which will create headaches for the general economy, but in terms of the stock market there should be a chance of it being lowered within a month if drastic actions are taken.
Volatility will be with us everywhere for a while
Silly question, near-zero chance according to VIX option prices.
Historically it appears that VIX takes about a year to drop from values above 40 to values below 20. Uneducated initial guess.
Never say never but this is pretty close to a sure zero. Even in the unlikely scenario where coronavirus concerns are resolved in a week or two will take months for market jitters to pass.
Base Rate heavy bet. From about June 07 to November 12, (remember then?) it never dropped below 15 multi-year chart:  https://www.macrotrends.net/2603/vix-volatility-index-historical-chart
